comments:
I get this exception (followed the help page with tips and tricks to set the 
environment up):

!SESSION Mon Jan 17 13:31:03 PST 2005 -----------------------------------------
-
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Jan 17, 2005 13:31:03.415
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.RuntimeException: Could not find framework
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.getBootPath(Main.java:395)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:174)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:704)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:688)

works fine for me.

The problem here I suspect is that the name of the workspace area.

To set up for feature-based self-hosting, you must launch Eclipse and point to 
a workspace directory whose last segment is 'plugins'

For example: eclipse -data D:/UpdatedSource/plugins

Example of what not to do: -data D:/UpdatedSource.

I launched eclipse with the following parameter:

-data  d:\newWorkspace\plugins


I'm using Version: 3.0.1.1 of Eclipse build.

I just did it again and it worked fine.

There is not much to it.
here are the steps again:

1. Launch Eclipse as in : eclipse -data D:/newworkspace/plugins
2. Use the "External Plug-ins and Fragments' wizard to import all plugins into 
your workspace.  Make sure you import WITHOUT links.  That is, in the "Import 
As" section on the first page of the import wizard, make sure the FIRST option 
is selected.
3. Import all features using the "External Features" import wizard.
4. Create a new runtime workbench launch configuration.
5. On the plugins tab of the launch config, choose the second option.
6. Run.

Please see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=83252.

I'm still getting the problem in the original description perhaps due to the 
fact that import of the feature doesn't succeed flawlessly.

bug 83252 is actually a dup of bug 70390 and has been fixed in the 3.0.2 
stream.

You can download the 3.0.2 build from today and enjoy that fix.

Report back if that made a difference.

If not, please write in detail what steps you performed or attach any 
particular features that are causing the problem.

That is, we need something more than "I tried the tips and tricks and it 
doesn't work"

Created an attachment (id=17321)
sample feature and sample plugin

Steps to reproduce:
1) download Eclipse 3.0.2 from www.eclipse.org and unzip it on your pc;
2) download the attached data.zip and unzip it to c:\temp dir;
3) start eclipse with the following param: "-data  d:\newWorkspace\plugins"
4) "Import... | External plugins and fragments", Next
5) uncheck "The target platform..." and type "D:\temp" in the "plug-in 
location" text box;
6) select "binary projects" in the "Import As" group, click Next;
7) double-click "sampleOne" plugin and click Finish
8) "Import... | External Features", Next;
9) uncheck "Choose..." and Browse to "D:\temp", Next, Finish
10) "Run | Run...", select "Run-time Workbench" and click "New"
11) for the New_configuration select "Plug-ins" tab and choose "Use features 
in the workspace (selected normal startup)";
12) Hit Run

RESULT: 

!SESSION Wed Jan 19 21:44:48 PST 2005 -----------------------------------------
-
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Jan 19, 2005 21:44:48.419
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.RuntimeException: Could not find framework
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.getBootPath(Main.java:395)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:174)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:704)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:688)

Created an attachment (id=17322)
sample feature+plugin

disregard another attachment. Use this one

Using Debug instead of Run in step #10 generates different error:

Error dialog says: Error (cannot connect to VM)
Console view says:
"
FATAL ERROR in native method: No transports initialized
err:: No such file or directory
Error [2] in connect() call!
Socket transport failed to init.
Transport dt_socket failed to initialize, rc = -1.
"

No wonder it didn't work.
You also have to import *all* plugins and features in your target platform.
Basically, all plugins and features that you are launching with must be in 
your workspace.

I understand this would be a pain for larget target platforms, but in feature-
based selfhosting, we play by Update Manager's rules and it requires all 
plugins and features to be in this layout.

bug 75079 is used to track any future changes that we could on the PDE side to 
simplify feature-based selfhosting, should there be a breakthrough in Update 
land that would allow us to do this.

Although this bug report should be resolved as worksforme, I will resolve it 
as dup of bug 75079 so that you would be notified when such a breakthrough 
occurs.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 75079 ***
